title: A Misinformation Pandemic
source: University of Minnesota School of Public Health
description: Misinformation about the pandemic is like COVID-19 itself: highly contagious, destructive, and with no known treatment or vaccine. Misinformation, and its nefarious brother, disinformation, causes confusion and, in some cases, death. In this episode we consider how to separate truth from lies and stop the spread of bad information.

title: Facts Aren't Enough
description: Sometimes when we believe something, we resist data that can change our minds. This week, we look at how we rely on the people we trust to shape what we believe, and why emotions can be more powerful than facts. This episode features new reporting and favorite conversations with neuroscientist Tali Sharot and philosopher of science Cailin Oâ€™Connor.

title: Philosophy of Medicine on COVID-19
description: An episode of the podcast Philosophers on Medicine revisiting a public panel discussion with Trisha Greenhalgh, Ross Upshur, Maya Goldenberg, Alex Broadbent, and Sang-Wook Yi, hosted by Jonathan Fuller.

title: Political Philosophy and the Pandemic
description: How should we think politically about the current global crisis? Do extreme circumstances reveal truths of political philosophy or do they reinforce whatever it is we already believe? Mark, Wes, Seth, and Dylan talk about applying philosophical insights to real-life situations rife with unknowns, John Rawls's veil of ignorance and Adam Smith on our interconnectedness, utilitarianism, libertarianism, and more.
